{ "step_by_step_thinking": "The density of a radiograph is determined by the amount of radiation that reaches the film. This is influenced by the milliamperage (mA), which controls the amount of current passing through the x-ray tube and thus the number of x-rays produced. The kilovoltage peak (kVp) also affects the density as it controls the energy of the x-rays, and thus their ability to penetrate the object. The thickness of the object also affects the density as thicker objects absorb more radiation, reducing the amount that reaches the film. However, the cone angulation does not affect the density of the radiograph. It affects the geometric distortion of the image, but not the amount of radiation that reaches the film.", "answer_choice": "C. Cone angulation" }
